<s>9<\s>12 
is a stout bony ridge or step which is peculiar  to the old male Ovibos. 
The fronto-nasal suture extends nearly at right angles to 
the median line instead of being directed <s>downwards<\s> 
obliquely forwards at a very acute angle as in the Ovis, Capra 
Bos and especially Bubalus Caffir. In the European Bison 
it runs at a slightly greater angle than in the Bovidae 
and then suddenly ends in a right angle with the median 
line X, while in the American it is straight throughout. 
The nasal bones are much wider posteriorly than 
anteriorly and their anterior extremities are much narrower than in the Bovidae & Capra; two points in which 
they approach Ovis and Capra XX. The Premaxillaries are 
slender and their sides converge anteriorly as in the Goats and 
Sheep while in Bubalus Bos and Gnu they are nearly 
parallel XXX. They do not extend as in Bos as far back the 
<s>Dental<\s> Nasals a character which they share with the Bison, they 
end in a small rounded extremity. The facial plate of 
the Maxillary is much more vertical in Ovibos and Ovis <s>and<\s> 
<s>Capra<\s> than in Bos, Bubalus <s>and<\s> or Bison and the facial ridge 
is represented by a stout boss above the root of the first true 
Molar as in Bubalus Caffir. The lachrymal bone also 
has a strong ovine <s>and Caprine<\s> character impressed upon 
<s> which varies in depth, is shallow in the female re that in the old male<\s> 
it in the broad deep excavation in front of the orbit. 
In the majority of the Antelopes, as the Gnu in common 
with the Oxen, Bison and Buffalo & Goat  this is absent 
in others however as the Boutebuck and the Eland it 
is also found. 
Orbits. The outward projection of the orbits differentiates distinguishes 
most strongly <s>the<\s> Ovibos from the true Bovidae and 
especially from Bubalus Caffir. In the Bison however 
the same character is found and is more developed 
in the European than in the American species. This is
